content.text: Table 1.1 lists some physical quantities. Complete the table by placing a tick \((\checkmark)\) next to the scalar quantities
Calculate the percentage uncertainties in \(D\) and \(L\). Write your answers in Table 1.2
Calculate the density of the cylinder. Give your answer to three significant figures
density =   .........  \(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{m}^{-3}\)
Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the density
percentage uncertainty =   .........  %
A uniform cylinder has diameter \(D\), length \(L\) and mass \(M\)
The density \(\rho\) of the cylinder is given by
Table 1.2 shows the data obtained from an experiment to determine the density of the cylinder
Show that the time \(t\) for the ball to reach the wall is \(0.95 \text{s}\)
Calculate the vertical component \(u_{\mathrm{V}}\) of the initial velocity of the ball
Determine \(h\)
The speed of the ball just after striking the wall is less than its speed just before striking the wall
State what this indicates about the nature of the collision of the ball with the wall
A ball on horizontal ground is kicked towards a vertical wall. Fig. 2.1 shows the path of the ball

The ball has an initial velocity \(u\) at an angle of \(38^{\circ}\) to the ground. The ball travels a horizontal distance of \(9.0 \text{m}\) before striking the wall at a height \(h\) above the ground. The horizontal component \(u_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the initial velocity of the ball is \(9.5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
Air resistance is negligible
State the conditions for a system to be in equilibrium
Calculate the volume of air displaced by the airship
When fully loaded, the weight of the airship is greater than the upthrust
To maintain horizontal flight, the fans provide a total vertical force of \(3.0 \times 10^{3} \text{N}\) upwards on the airship
Calculate the mass of the airship
Fig. 3.1 shows an airship in flight. The airship is propelled by identical fans that can be angled to control the motion of the airship
The upthrust on the airship is \(93 000 \text{N}\)
The density of the surrounding air is \(1.2 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\)
the change in momentum \(\Delta p\) of the air propelled through the fan blades in this time
the speed of the air as it leaves the fan
the total kinetic energy of this air due to its movement through the fan
kinetic energy =   .........  J
At a certain time, the airship in **(b)** is stationary. The thrust force exerted by a fan on the airship is 2800 N

To produce this force, a mass of \(64\mathrm{kg}\) of air is propelled through the blades of the fan in a time of \(0.50\mathrm{s}\). Assume that this air is initially stationary at the entrance to the fan
Calculate:
state what is represented by the gradient
explain why the area under the line represents the elastic potential energy of the wire
For the lines in Fig. 4.1:
Use Fig. 4.1 to determine:
● the extension \(x_{\mathrm{G}}\) of wire G
● the extension \(x_{\mathrm{H}}\) of wire H
Calculate the total elastic potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the composite wire due to the weight of the block
The original length of wire G is \(L\) and the original length of wire H is \(1.5L\)
Calculate the ratio

content.blockMath: \[\frac{\text{cross-sectional area of wire G}}{\text{cross-sectional area of wire H}}\]

content.text: Wires G and H are joined together end-to-end to form a composite wire of negligible weight. The composite wire hangs vertically from a fixed support
Fig. 4.1 shows the variation with extension \(x\) of the tensile force \(F\) for two wires, G and H, made from the same material
The elastic limit has not been exceeded for G or H
the position of an interference maximum (label this cross Y)
the position of an interference minimum (label this cross Z)
On Fig. 5.1, mark with a cross \((\times)\):
Calculate the separation \(a\) of the sources A and B
State the principal region of the electromagnetic spectrum to which the waves belong
The waves in air have a wavelength of \(2.9 \times 10^{- 5} \text{m}\)
An interference pattern is detected along a line parallel to AB and at a perpendicular distance of \(140 \text{m}\) from AB. The spacing between adjacent interference maxima is \(1.2 \text{cm}\)
Two point sources, A and B, produce coherent electromagnetic waves. The waves from A and B are emitted in phase and have wavelength \(\lambda\), as shown in Fig. 5.1
The lines on Fig. 5.1 represent wavefronts. All the points on a wavefront are in phase
Calculate the speed of the train
State the relationship between amplitude \(A\) and intensity \(I\) for a progressive wave
On Fig. 6.3, sketch the variation with \(d / x_0\) of \(A / A_0\)
The train approaches and then passes the observer. The intensity \(I\) of the sound heard by the observer varies with the distance \(d\) of the horn from the observer
When the horn is at a distance \(\mathsf{x}_0\) from the observer, the intensity \(I\) of the sound heard is \(I_0\) and the amplitude \(A\) of the sound wave at the observer is \(A_0\)
Fig. 6.2 shows the variation with \(d / x_0\) of \(I / I_0\) as the train moves away from the observer
Fig. 6.3
A train travels at constant speed along a straight horizontal track towards an observer standing adjacent to the track, as shown in Fig. 6.1

The train sounds its horn continuously as it approaches the observer. The horn emits a sound of constant frequency \(251\mathrm{Hz}\). The frequency of sound heard by the observer is \(291\mathrm{Hz}\). The speed of sound in air is \(340\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
State Ohm's law
Calculate the resistivity \(\rho\) of the material of the resistance wire
The switch is open
State the reading on the voltmeter
voltmeter reading =   .........  V
The switch is now closed
State whether there is an increase, decrease or no change to:
● the current in the battery
● the voltmeter reading
The switch remains closed. The slider S is moved along the resistance wire so that the voltmeter reading is 3.1V
On Fig. 7.1, draw a cross \((\times)\) on the resistance wire to show a possible new position of the slider.

A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(6.2 \text{V}\) and negligible internal resistance is connected in a circuit to a uniform resistance wire, a voltmeter, a fixed resistor and a switch, as shown in Fig. 7.1
The resistance wire has resistance \(18\Omega\), length \(0.94 \text{m}\) and cross-sectional area \(7.2 \times 10^{-8} \text{m}^2\). The slider S is positioned half-way along the length of the wire
Determine the charge \(q\) of a charge carrier in the wire suggested by this data
With reference to the value of \(q\), explain why the data recorded by the student cannot be correct
The circuit in **(b)** is altered by changing the battery for one of a different e.m.f
The switch is open
A student records the following data for the resistance wire:
current in the wire 0.93A
mean drift speed of charge carriers \(1.3 \times 10^{-3} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\)
number density of charge carriers \(9.0 \times 10^{28} \text{m}^{-3}\)
For the nuclide \(^{23}_{12}\mathrm{Mg}\), state what is represented by the numbers 23 and 12
23 represents:
12 represents:
Complete the equation by inserting the missing numbers
State the name of the group (class) of fundamental particles to which the positron and neutrino belong
The nuclide \(^{23}_{12}\mathrm{Mg}\) is an isotope of magnesium that undergoes \(\beta^{+}\) decay to form a new nuclide X according to the equation
Four numbers are missing from the equation
A radioactive source emits particles from its nuclei when it decays
Fig. 8.1 shows, for the source, the variation with kinetic energy of the number of particles emitted
State how Fig. 8.1 shows that these nuclei do **not** undergo beta-decay
